name: «Simulacra»
subtitle: [re]presentations for large chamber ensemble and electronics
notes:
phase i: reflection
	phase ii: masking/denaturing
	phase iii: masking/absence
	phase iv: simulacrum

In Simulacra and Simulation (1981), French sociologist Jean Baudrillard questions the extent to which contemporary Western culture and society can be said to be rooted in reality, as opposed to symbolically mediated simulations of it.

These simulations or representations can be further differentiated according to the degree of detachment from their original, going from transparent copies, to counterfeit, to simulacrum — copies that precede their original, or have no original whatsoever.

In «Simulacra», free re-interpretations of these ideas appear, where the duality of the original and its copies are found in the use of instruments and recordings of them, acoustic vs. electroacoustic sounds, real vs. simulated speech, or musical materials and their different instantiations.
commission: Commissioned by the Chicago Center for Contemporary Composition at the University of Chicago

performances.event: Grossman Ensemble with Tim Weiss, conductor

name: «Enjambres»
subtitle: for large chamber ensemble
notes: In «Enjambres», the ensemble is imagined as a meta-instrument, in which individual parts come together to form swarm-like gestures. Through iterations of these gestures different musical processes emerge, until reaching a cacophonous, machine-like state.
commission: Commissioned by Alarm Will Sound and Alan Pierson for the 2020 Mizzou International Composer Festival

performances.event: Alarm Will Sound: Eight world premieres

name: «Danzas encefálicas»
subtitle: Dream cycles for sinfonietta and electronics
notes: The electro-encephalogram or EEG has been an essential tool in sleep research, allowing the study of brain activity during such state. This data-recording method makes it possible to identify various patterns of sleep, consisting of REM or Rapid eye movement stages — i.e. dreaming— and NREM or Non-rapid eye movement stages — i.e. sleeping. Charting each of these different states over a time axis results in a hypnogram, which can vary from sleep to sleep, and from human to human — However, many shared features or statistic expectations still arise from them. This inherent consistency might hence suggest one of many other possible questions to a composer: If sleeping and dreaming are natural phenomena with clear pattern behaviors, deep-rooted in our cognitive system, would using a hypnogram for musical mapping reveal something about the way we listen?.
commission: Commissioned by and premiered by the IU New Music Ensemble through the Dean's Prize Commission and Award

name: «La mirada del Ouroboros»
subtitle: concerto for harp and sinfonietta
notes:
The ouroboros (from the Greek οὐρά, “tail” and βόρος, “devouring”) is an ancient symbol of cyclicality and infinity depicted by a serpent eating its own tail. This circular and self-devouring inclination is in essence the driving force behind «La Mirada del Ouroboros». The translation of such a symbol into sound is carried out through the idea of amputated repetitions, in which musical materials appear iteratively in increasingly incomplete presentations, thus giving a sense of imminent exhaustion.

Likewise, the role of the soloist is linked to this image. The gradual changes of the harp pedal mechanism serve as harmonic catalysts to underscore the pitch content upon which the rest of the ensemble interacts. Such changes follow common-tone-based patterns, whose function is to eventually lead to the same point of departure, thus outlining a full harmonic cycle from beginning to end.

This circular behavior is simultaneously paired with an implementation of both symmetric proportions and golden ratio. These two elements are crucial during the musical development, as they often balance the pacing, shape, and organization in time of most musical events.

The immanent conflict between self-destruction and self-creation in the ouroboros also lends itself to the nature and character of the musical gestures. The images of sound structures falling apart and coming together, violent and delicate instrumental techniques, abrupt and organic transitions between sections, are all derived elements from this idea. At heart, this piece is an invitation to experience eye-to-eye the ouroboros inextricably unfolding in front of the listener.
commission: Written for and commissioned by Bibiana Ordoñez Velandia, with the support of the art endowment fund 'Beca para la creación de música contemporánea, Ministerio de Cultura de Colombia'

name: «Di.ver.ti.men.to»
subtitle: allegro-remix for string trio
notes:
The title of this piece, «Di.ver.ti.men.to», refers to both the spirit of playfulness in which it was written, as well as its source material, the 1st movement from W. A. Mozart’s Divertimento in E flat K.563 for String Trio.

Borrowing from sampling and remix traditions, the piece consists exclusively of short segments from Mozart’s work, each individually re-arranged and manipulated in different ways — .e.g., transposed, stretched, spectrally distorted, etc. — to create a dance-like, disjointed, humorous, and sometimes riotous experience.
commission: Commissioned by Guarneri Hall NFP and NEXUS Chamber Music

performances.event: Ravinia Festival - NEXUS Chamber Music: Dancing with the Shadow

name: «Canticum»
subtitle: for carillon and electronics
notes: «Canticum» is an interplay between contemplative and discursive musical moments, delineated by a gradual trajectory from immersive, resonant sounds to more energetic and bright bursts of energy. Its slow-evolving nature is meant to open the possibility for listeners to experience these sounds with different levels of focus, ranging from a soundscape to a foregrounded musical experience.
commission: Commissioned by Rockefeller Chapel for the 90th Anniversary of the Rockefeller Chapel Carillon

performances.event: 2O22 Guild of Carilloneurs of North America (GCNA) Congress: Opening concert

name: «...como la pólvora...»
subtitle: attractors for amplified string quartet
notes: «…como la pólvora…» is motivated by an interest in juxtaposing repetition and unpredictability through the use of fingering patterns and string harmonics. The wide range of string harmonics and the ways in which they are played, makes it so that the sounds are highly volatile and inconsistent every time they are played. Yet, by iterating through different patterns, it becomes possible to supersede the continuous flux and variation of these sounds.
commission: Commissioned by the Chicago Center for Contemporary Composition at the University of Chicago

performances.venue: Fulton Recital Hall, University of Chicago

name: «Introducción a la esquizofrenia»
subtitle: praeludium for string quartet
notes:
«Introducción a la esquizofrenia» rests on the idea of juxtaposing reality with distortions thereof. The use of the term schizophrenia in the title is simply meant as a metaphor or allusion to the nature of such distortions, which are essential to the unfolding of the musical discourse — particularly, distortions affecting the linear perception of time.

These distortions act intertextually upon an external reality, here represented by a fairly well-known musical work, which will reveal itself throughout the course of the piece. This work is thus de- and re-composed in different ways, such that the listener has the opportunity to experience a mild sense of doubt or uncertainty about what is and isn’t real.
commission: Commissioned by FilarMed for the Nacido En Cuarentena event series

name: «Ruido, ceniza»
subtitle: morphisms for one or more amplified string instruments
notes: «Ruido, ceniza» takes gradual change as a foundation for musical discourse, and heavily relies on smooth interpolations between different types of fast, periodic sounds. Slow, seamless transitions between these sounds become then paramount, highlighting the interplay between degrees of instrumental control and lack thereof. These circumstances inevitably require the player to actively take part in narrowing down the sound possibilities, both prior to and during the performance, resulting in a noise-based minimalism of sorts. The piece can be performed by any number of string instruments as long as they're amplified.

performances.venue: Auer Hall, Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music

name: «Umbra»
subtitle: semi-improvisation for light.void~, handmade digital photo-controller
notes: «Umbra» is an exploration of embodiment as a point of departure for composition, improvisation, and performance, through the use of a handmade digital photo-controller named light.void~. The act of considering the choreography involved in the production of a given sound as a basis for deciding what the sound itself will be becomes here paramount, both prior to and during the performance. From this approach emerges a fairly distinctive gestural vocabulary that not only shapes the sounds in real time, but also the surrounding space in the form of light cutting through the darkness.

performances.venue: Auer Hall, Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music

name: «Ataxia»
subtitle: for English horn and live electronics
notes:
Primarily a medical term for lack of control over bodily movements, «Ataxia» [a- ‘without’ + taxis ’order’] delves into the musical significance of tensions between smoothness and irregularity, as well as invariance and change. These tensions are explored at different temporal scales, from the destabilization of short musical gestures, to semi-gradual, almost abrupt transitions between larger sections.

The lyrical and expressive qualities traditionally associated with this instrument are also subject to this idea, by imposing less conventional, technical challenges to it. Additionally, subtle dramatic components are introduced throughout the performance to elucidate a struggle for control between technology and the human body.

name: «Paroxismos»
subtitle: mosaic on violence for chamber ensemble
notes: «Paroxismos» is based on the nature of violence, both as a mechanism of tyranny and of liberation. From this understanding emerges a relentless use of aggressive instrumental gestures, disruptions of continuity and periodicity, and imminent fragmentations of sound structures. Violence is therefore inflicted both by and upon the performers — the former through the use of extreme physicality in sound production, and the latter as an oppressive denial of change through excessive repetitions.
commission: Commissioned by the Society of Composers, Inc. (SCI) and the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP) for the 2019 SCI National Conference

name: «Arborescencia»
subtitle: birdsong for flute and live electronics
notes:
«Arborescencia» circles around utterances of tree-like gestures and representations in music, taking the phenomenon of branching as a metaphor or model to derive musical events from. This tendency manifests itself both vertically — timbre and harmony — and horizontally — duration, rhythm, and time — with a particular emphasis on the perceptual domain.

The listener might then be able to notice instantiations of arborescence through the segmentation of the flute sound into multiple spectral strands, entangled rhythms that arise from juxtaposition of echoes, harmonies that stem and grow from the flute lines, or hierarchically established repetitions and fragmentations of sound sequences. Just like in trees, one might also occasionally hear semblances of chirps and warbles of the birds that inhabit them.
commission: Commissioned by José Martinez through the 2018-2019 Rainwater Innovation Grant from University of Texas at Austin

name: «...de lo voluble...»
subtitle: roulette for chamber ensemble
notes: «… de lo voluble…» focuses on fastness and constant flux as a means to explore perceptual phenomena and recognition of musical events. Given the dependency between repetition and long-term memory, different approaches to iterations of musical events are central to this work and shape the formal scheme of the music. Such scheme behaves in a rotational, roulette-like fashion, which is also meant to play with the expectations of the listener at a macro-formal level.
commission: Commissioned by Ensamble Periscopio in celebration of the 20th anniversary of Universidad EAFIT's Music Department

performances.venue: Auer Hall, Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music

name: «El impulso sumergido»
subtitle: rêverie for viola da gamba and live electronics
notes:
«El impulso sumergido» (“The submerged impulse”) is abstractly conceived as a musical depiction of a contained, suppressed, noumenal force, fighting its way up into the surface. This idea of emergence is primarily portrayed through the slowly-expanding register of the viol, as well as an obscure-to-bright harmonic trajectory throughout the piece. As a means of highlighting this process, the live electronics undertake the role of either hampering or reinforcing the resonance of the open strings of the instrument, as well as its spectral components.

This piece is commissioned by, and written for viol player Brady Lanier, whose personal interests in pop music and culture are widely reflected in the music, interacting likewise with those of the composer.

performances.event: Indiana University Center for Electronic and Computer Music: Spring concert
performances.venue: Auer Hall, Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music

name: «Los trópicos ocultos»
subtitle: proloquor for solo trumpet and chamber ensemble
notes:
The title, «Los Trópicos Ocultos» ("The Hidden Tropics") is intended as a semantic representation of how the sound world of the piece behaves in time. The word “Tropic”, from Greek ‘tropikos' or Late Latin ‘tropicus', meaning a “turn” or "change", refers to the cyclical and rotating nature in which the musical ideas and elements co-exist. This term also alludes to those imaginary places — or tropics — that are created by an underlying musical idea which, although not easily recognizable, is always present.

In addition, this concept is partly achieved by the manipulation of the work's musical structure, wherein the linear musical discourse is distorted to influence the listener's perception of the time. The quote from Gaspar Noé’s film « Irreversible » (« Le temps détruit tout »), spoken by the performers during the course of the piece, is used as a poetic and dramatic means to underscore this premise.

name: «¡Carnaval del Diablo!»
subtitle: matachinesque ritual for clarinet and electronics
notes:
Every two years, a six-day carnival is held in a small Colombian town called «Riosucio». A carnival in which the Devil himself is the main figure and host; not as the commonly known biblical and malign force, but rather as a satirical, hedonistic and irreverent being who welcomes everyone to join in for celebration: a celebration that, in its core, is as structured as any other ritual or ceremony.

It is then, in the spirit of capturing the excitement and eccentricity of this weird festivity, that «¡Carnaval del Diablo!» is brought to music and pays tribute — in a very strange manner — to diversion, euphoria and pleasure.

name: «O llanto místico»
subtitle: threnody for solo organ
notes:
O llanto místico ("Mystical weeping") is a meditative, yet quite dramatic work that serves as a musical reflection of several personal thoughts regarding human tragedy.

«O llanto místico» was originally written to be premiered with the 3-manual, 68-stop, Seward Organ C.B Fisk, Op. 135, located in Auer Hall, Indiana University (Bloomington, IN, USA).

performances.venue: Auer Hall, Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music

name: «Oh, misteriosa alma mía»
subtitle: a nadaist poem for mixed choir a cappella
notes:
Oh, misteriosa alma mía
¿dónde esperas encontrar tu amor
en qué mar dejarás caer tu última lágrima
dónde por fin olvidarás la muerte
en qué navío de la desgracia serás feliz
bajo qué árbol, bajo qué cielo
bajo qué puñado de polvo
darás reposo a tu pobre esqueleto?
¿De qué desierto te llegará el olivo?
¿Y esta gaviota mi alma
hacia qué Islas Desventuradas volará?
Y la Gran Fiesta del Cuerpo
¿será para después en el Tiempo Inmóvil? ¿Florecerá sobre mi tumba la Siempreviva? ¿Podré ser Eterno bajo mi pavorosa ceniza? ¡Responde, Alma mía!
Mátame de silencios, pero habla.
Haz aunque sea un viraje a la desgracia
pero cesa ya de buscar;
El mundo es redondo y no hay salvación.
No olvides que en tu locura
has creído encontrar el último Puerto,
pero siempre has bajado en él
para volver a partir.
Ahora mi corazón se abre a una nueva esperanza, a un nuevo mar.
No sé si gime o canta
pero se agita dentro de mí.
Adivino su inquietud que dice:
Nunca llegarás, amigo mío.
¡Hay que partir siempre!
Al mar digo que sí con una condición:
Aquí o en la Eternidad
mi corazón pasajero exige ser Eterno.

	- Gonzalo Arángo

performances.venue: Auer Hall, Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music
Auer Hall, Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music

name: «Un arracacho en La Heroica»
subtitle: for cello and piano
notes: «Un arracacho en la Heroica» is a simple piece, inspired by traditional Colombian music rhythms. It uses modal languages to evoke dances such as bambuco or pasillo while also making use of sonorities reminiscent of French impressionism.

name: «Hýpnos»
subtitle: for harp, clarinet, and cello
notes: «Hýpnos» is, in Greek mythology, the embodiment of sleep and dreams — a topic that has been at the center of some of my works. In essence, the piece is descriptive and evocative of those concepts through the treatment of timbre, texture, and harmony, without following a specific programatic narrative. Likewise, it explores some of the different technical possibilities and capabilities of the harp, which at the same time become themselves a source of other musical materials.

name: «Camazotz»
subtitle: for string quartet
notes:
Camazotz, a deity that in Mesoamerican mythology is represented by an anthropomorphic bat, is the germinal idea behind this string quartet. Two musical themes come into play to portray the duality of the animal and the human in Camazotz — one theme is energetic and defiant, while the other more lucid and calmer.

This piece is dedicated to the TAYRONA string quartet.
